docs.title: BirdTalk Documentation
docs.text: BirdTalk is an iOS app designed to be controlled by spoken instructions, allowing you to record bird observations in the field hands-free, while keeping your phone in your pocket. Using simple voice commands, you can create eBird checklists without taking your eyes off the birds or handling your device.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Voice control for hands-free operation
  • Integration with eBird
  • Bluetooth device compatibility

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Requirements and Installation: Everything you need to get started with BirdTalk
  • Getting Started: Essential commands and detailed tutorial for using BirdTalk
  • Uploading Checklists: Step-by-step guide to uploading your checklists to eBird
  • Command Reference: Complete reference for all BirdTalk voice commands
  • Tips and Tricks: Helpful advice for getting the most out of BirdTalk
  • FAQ: Answers to frequently asked questions about BirdTalk

docs.title: About BirdTalk
docs.text: BirdTalk is currently in beta testing through TestFlight. The app is designed to enhance the birding experience by allowing birders to maintain their focus on birds while easily recording their observations.

docs.title: Acknowledgments
docs.text:
BirdTalk is developed by Steve Colwell with major assistance from iOS expert Lee Hasiuk. Many thanks to the early Santa Barbara testers: Mark Holmgren, Sue Cook, David Blue, and Conor McMahon. Much appreciated documentation support by John Callender.

For support or feedback, contact Steve at stevebt@membot.com.

docs.title: What is BirdTalk's relationship with eBird?
docs.text: BirdTalk is a voice-controlled interface for creating and uploading eBird checklists. When you're ready to upload your checklists, you'll enter your eBird credentials in your phone's browser to complete the upload.

docs.title: Do I need an internet connection?
docs.text:
Required for:

  • Initial installation and first-time setup
  • Uploading checklists

Not required for:

  • Creating checklists in the field
  • Recording observations
  • Location recording

docs.title: How does BirdTalk handle location information?
docs.text:
• Records location for each observation
  • Location data helps with hotspot detection and checklist organization

docs.title: Why does BirdTalk sometimes take longer to respond?
docs.text:
• BirdTalk waits for silence to know you've finished speaking
  • In quiet conditions: responds within 1 second
  • With background noise (wind, traffic): may take up to 3 seconds
  • Solution: Wait for a quiet moment or speak more clearly

docs.title: How can I improve voice recognition?
docs.text:
1. Speak clearly and consistently
  2. If a command isn't recognized, repeat the exact same phrase

  3. In noisy conditions:

  4. Speak slightly louder

  5. Position microphone closer
  6. Wait for quieter moments

docs.title: What if BirdTalk doesn't recognize a bird name?
docs.text:
• Try using a unique part of the name
  • Repeat the exact same phrase
  • Check the command reference for shorthand examples
  • Once a species is in your checklist, its name gets priority for recognition

docs.title: Note About Merlin Sound ID
docs.text: Due to a recent update, Merlin Sound ID is no longer compatible with BirdTalk. The apps cannot run simultaneously.

docs.title: Will I hear notifications while using BirdTalk?
docs.text:
• BirdTalk itself doesn't affect notifications
  • Use an Apple Watch to receive notifications

docs.title: Which Bluetooth headset should I use?
docs.text:
We recommend the OpenComm2 Bone Conduction Headset because:

  • Leaves ears unobstructed for birding
  • Has a boom microphone for better voice recognition
  • Provides good noise isolation
  • Uses bone conduction technology

docs.title: How do I manage multiple Bluetooth devices?
docs.text:
iPhone can handle two audio devices:

  • Internal mic/speaker
  • One Bluetooth device

Additional information:

  • Most recently connected device takes control
  • Turn Bluetooth headset off then on to put headset back in control.

docs.title: How do I manage multiple checklists?
docs.text:
• You can have multiple incomplete checklists
  • Use "Stop checklist" to pause current checklist
  • Start new checklist when location changes
  • Upload checklists when you have internet connection

docs.title: Can I edit checklists after creation?
docs.text:
Yes:

  • Use "Insert checklist" to split observations into separate lists
  • "Scratch" removes checklist headers to combine lists
  • Edit comments and counts at any time
  • Review and mark entries before uploading

docs.title: How do I prepare for birding in a new location?
docs.text:
1. Make sure you've completed the initial setup
  2. You can bird offline in any location
  3. Remember to upload checklists when back online

docs.title: What information does BirdTalk collect?
docs.text:
• Logs voice recognition attempts for improvement
  • Stores phonetic format of commands (not readable text)
  • Uses GPS data for hotspot detection and location recording
  • All data is used solely for app functionality and debugging

docs.title: Can I opt out of data collection?
docs.text:
• When muted or checklist stopped, no logging occurs
  • Use "Shut down" to completely stop all app functions
  • Contact developer for specific privacy concerns

docs.title: What if my headset stops working?
docs.text:
1. Try power cycling the headset
  2. Turn headset off and back on to reset audio
  3. Check Bluetooth connections in iPhone Settings
  4. Ensure headset is most recently connected device

docs.title: Why can't I upload my checklist?
docs.text:
Common reasons:

  • No internet connection
  • Marked (red) entries need review
  • Not selected on checklist header

Solution:

  • Unmark entries
  • Select header
  • Ensure internet connection

docs.title: What if I lose GPS signal?
docs.text:
• BirdTalk continues recording observations
  • Location data may be less accurate
  • Consider adding location notes in memos

docs.title: Getting Started with BirdTalk
docs.text: This guide will help you start using BirdTalk effectively. It begins with a quick reference of essential features and interface elements, then provides a detailed tutorial with real-world examples.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: BirdTalk starting screen

docs.title: The Basics
docs.text:
When you first open BirdTalk, you'll see the main screen with options to start a new checklist or access previous ones. The interface is clean and simple, designed for hands-free operation. Use pinch-to-zoom gestures to adjust text size for better visibility.

Before starting your birding session:

  • Test voice recognition by saying "Time"
  • BirdTalk should respond with the current time
  • If using a Bluetooth headset:
    • Turn it on before starting BirdTalk
    • BirdTalk will automatically use the headset
    • For audio issues, see Tips and Tricks

docs.title: Essential Commands
docs.text:
Location selection screen showing nearby hotspots

Starting a Checklist

Say "Start checklist" and BirdTalk will find your location and suggest the nearest eBird hotspot. If the suggested hotspot isn't correct:

  • Say "Next" to see other nearby options
  • Or tap a different hotspot on the screen

Recording Birds

Screen for adding bird observations

Use the basic format: Say "[Number] [Species Name]". For example:

  • Say "Three mockingbirds"
  • Say "One robin"
  • Say "Two cal quail" (shorthand for California Quail)

Viewing Your List

BirdTalk offers multiple ways to organize your observations:

  • Say "sort by time" (default)
  • Say "sort by family"

Observations sorted by time (default)

Observations sorted by family

Managing Observation Counts

Here are the essential commands for managing your observations:

  • To check a count: Say "How many robins"
  • To change the last entry: Say "No three"
  • To add one: Say "One more"
  • To subtract one: Say "One fewer"
  • To change species: Say "No towhee"

Getting Help

Help screen showing available commands

The help screen is always available - just say "Help"

Say "Back" to return from the Help screen.

docs.title: Detailed Tutorial
docs.text: Now let's walk through a complete birding session, showing how BirdTalk works in real-world scenarios.

docs.title: Starting Your Session
docs.text:
• Turn on your Bluetooth headset
  • Open BirdTalk
  • Say "Time" to verify voice recognition
  • Say "Start checklist"
  • BirdTalk suggests "Stow Lake, San Francisco, US-CA"
  • Start birding if correct, or say "Next" to step through available locations

docs.title: First Observations
docs.text:
• You hear a Song Sparrow:

    • Say "Song Sparrow"
    • BirdTalk adds one Song Sparrow

  • You see three Mallards:

    • Say "Three Mallards"
    • BirdTalk adds three Mallards

  • Another Song Sparrow singing:

    • Say "Choose Song Sparrow"
    • Say "One more"
    • Say "Memo singing" (adds breeding behavior note)

docs.title: Advanced Features
docs.text:
Correcting Mistakes

  • Species correction:

    • Say "Black Phoebe"
    • Realize it's actually a Say's Phoebe
    • Say "No Say's Phoebe"
    • BirdTalk changes the species

  • Count correction:

    • Say "Twelve Western Gulls"
    • Recount shows fourteen
    • Say "No fourteen"
    • BirdTalk updates the count
    • You could also say "two more"

Using Shorthand Names

  • For Yellow-rumped Warbler:

    • Say "Yellow Rump" or just "Rump"

  • For Pacific-slope Flycatcher:

    • Say "Slope"

Adding Comments

  • For behavior notes:

    • Say "Choose Yellow Rump"
    • Say "Memo foraging with chickadees"

  • For location notes:

    • Say "Memo near stone bridge coordinates"
    • BirdTalk automatically replaces the term "coordinates" with the GPS coordinates where you initially entered that species observation
    • You can also say "Memo near current coordinates." The phrase "current coordinates" will be replaced with the coordinates where you were when you issued the command.

docs.title: Managing Multiple Species
docs.text:
Mixed Flock Example

  • Record multiple species quickly:

    • Say "Three Chickadees"
    • Say "Two Ruby Crowned Kinglets"
    • Say "Yellow Rump"

  • Add behavior notes:

    • Say "Choose Chickadee"
    • Say "Memo foraging with kinglets and warbler"
    • Say "Choose Kinglet"
    • Say "Memo actively feeding in willows"

Quick Counts and Reviews

  • Check specific species:

    • Say "How many Song Sparrows"

  • Check total species:

    • Say "How many species"

docs.title: Uploading to eBird
docs.text: For detailed instructions on uploading your checklists to eBird, see Uploading Checklists. You can upload a single checklist immediately, or mark several checklists to upload together later.

docs.title: Tips for Success
docs.text:
• Keep commands simple and direct
  • Use shorthand names when they're unique in your area
  • Add memos while observations are fresh
  • Review your checklist before uploading
  • Use "upload later" if you want to double-check details

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If BirdTalk doesn't recognize a command:

  • Speak more clearly and slightly louder
  • Try repeating the exact same phrase
  • In noisy conditions, you may need to speak louder

If text is hard to read:

  • Use pinch-to-zoom gestures to adjust text size
  • Zoom in for better visibility in bright sunlight
  • Zoom out to see more content at once

If you make a mistake:

  • Say "Scratch that" to remove the last entry
  • Say "Restore" if you remove something by mistake

For more advanced features and commands, see the Command Reference.

Continue to Uploading Checklists.

docs.title: Speaking Techniques
docs.text:
• Speak clearly and consistently
  • Use the same phrase when repeating commands
  • Wait for quiet moments in noisy conditions
  • Position microphone closer in windy conditions
  • Speak slightly louder with background noise
  • Try cupping your hand around the microphone
  • Whispering, or whispering + cupping, can be effective when you want to avoid disturbing birds

docs.title: Bird Names
docs.text:
• Use unique parts of names for faster recognition
  • Try using just part of the name (e.g., say "shrike" instead of "loggerhead shrike")
  • Shorter names often work better as they're less likely to be misheard
  • Once a species is in your checklist, its name gets priority
  • Check the Command Reference for shorthand options
  • Repeat the exact same phrase if not recognized initially
  • Experiment with different shorthands to find what works best for problematic species

docs.title: Response Times
docs.text:
• Normal response: within 1 second in quiet conditions
  • May take up to 3 seconds with background noise
  • BirdTalk waits for silence to know you've finished speaking
  • Be patient in noisy environments

docs.title: New Location Checklist
docs.text:
1. Start a checklist at your location
  2. BirdTalk will suggest the nearest hotspot
  3. You can bird offline after initial setup
  4. Upload checklists when back online

docs.title: Managing Multiple Checklists
docs.text:
• Create separate checklists for different locations
  • Use "Stop checklist" to pause current list
  • Start new checklist when changing locations
  • "Insert checklist" splits observations into separate lists
  • "Scratch" removes headers to combine lists

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
• BirdTalk itself doesn't affect notifications
  • Use Apple Watch for important notifications

docs.title: Note About Merlin Sound ID
docs.text: Due to a recent update, Merlin Sound ID is no longer compatible with BirdTalk. The apps cannot run simultaneously.

docs.title: Bluetooth Management
docs.text:
iPhone handles two audio sources:

  • Internal mic/speaker
  • One Bluetooth device

Additional information:

  • Most recently connected device takes control
  • Turn Bluetooth headset on/off to switch devices if needed
  • Turn Bluetooth headset on/off if having connection issues

docs.title: Optimizing Audio Setup
docs.text:
1. Connect Bluetooth headset before starting BirdTalk
  2. Test voice recognition in different environments
  3. If needed, turn Bluetooth headset off/on to switch audio devices

docs.title: Before Uploading
docs.text:
• Review marked (red) entries
  • Ensure you've selected the checklist location header
  • Check internet connection
  • Verify all entries are unmarked

docs.title: Editing Options
docs.text:
• Edit comments and counts at any time
  • Review entries before uploading
  • Split or combine checklists as needed

docs.title: What Works Offline
docs.text:
• Creating new checklists
  • Recording observations
  • Adding comments and counts

docs.title: What Needs Internet
docs.text:

  • Uploading checklists to eBird

docs.title: Audio Issues
docs.text: • Say "Time" to check which device is handling the audio

docs.title: Audio Issues
docs.text:
1. Power cycle Bluetooth headset
  2. Turn headset off and back on to reset audio
  3. Check Bluetooth connections in Settings
  4. Ensure headset is recently connected

1. Try exact same phrase again
  2. Switch microphones

  4. Position microphone closer

docs.title: Uploading Checklists to eBird
docs.text: This guide walks you through the complete process of uploading your BirdTalk checklists to eBird, including both immediate uploads and managing saved checklists for later upload.

docs.title: Option 1: Upload Immediately
docs.text:
When you finish a checklist, you can upload it right away. The process is straightforward:

  1. Select your checklist by tapping the header or saying "Select checklist"
  2. Tap the upload button (up arrow pointing to cloud)
  3. Follow the prompts to complete the upload

The upload form where you'll enter your eBird credentials

The upload form provides all the necessary fields for submitting your checklist to eBird. Take a moment to review the details before submitting.

A closer look at the form fields

docs.title: Option 2: Save for Later Upload
docs.text:
Sometimes you might want to save checklists to upload them later. This is useful when you want to:

  • Review your observations more carefully
  • Wait for a better internet connection
  • Upload multiple checklists at once
  • Continue birding without interruption

Selecting a checklist to mark for later upload

To save a checklist for later:

  1. Select your checklist
  2. Say "Upload later" or use the menu options

The checklist is now marked for later upload

You can mark multiple checklists for later upload, which is particularly useful when you're doing several short counts in one area.

Multiple checklists marked for upload

docs.title: Upload Process
docs.text:
When you're ready to upload your saved checklists, BirdTalk provides clear guidance through each step.

Upload help page with instructions

The file selection process is straightforward:

The file selection popup

Selecting your checklist file

Once you've selected your file, you'll see the upload form ready for submission:

Form ready for submission

During the upload, BirdTalk shows a progress indicator:

Upload in progress indicator

Upon successful upload, you'll see confirmation screens:

Success confirmation

Detailed confirmation screen

Upload process completed

After successful upload, BirdTalk marks the checklists as uploaded and collapses them:

Checklists marked as uploaded and collapsed

Note: If you need to re-upload a checklist (for example, if there was an error during upload), you can use the "Unfreeze" command to mark it as not uploaded. See the Command Reference for details.

docs.title: Tips for Successful Uploads
docs.text:
A few key points to ensure smooth uploads:

  • Ensure you have a stable internet connection
  • Have your eBird credentials ready
  • Review your checklists before uploading
  • You can upload multiple checklists at once

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If you encounter issues during upload:

  • Check your internet connection
  • Verify your eBird credentials
  • Make sure all entries are unmarked (no red text)
  • Try uploading one checklist at a time if uploading multiple lists fails

docs.title: BirdTalk Command Reference
docs.text: This guide provides a comprehensive list of all BirdTalk commands, organized by category. Commands are listed in order of most commonly used within each category.

docs.title: Starting and Stopping
docs.text:
• Say Start checklist - Begins a new checklist at current location
  • Say Stop checklist - Ends current checklist
  • Say Resume - Resumes a stopped checklist
  • Say Upload later - Saves current checklist for later upload to eBird
  • Say Shut down - Turns off BirdTalk completely (note: app remains running but won't respond to voice commands)

docs.title: Basic Bird Entry
docs.text:
• Say three mockingbirds - Records multiple birds of a species
  • Say one robin - Records a single bird
  • Say mockingbird - Records one bird (number defaults to 1)

Shorthand examples:

  • Say cal quail → California Quail
  • Say slope → Pacific-slope Flycatcher
  • Say yellow-crown → Yellow-crowned Night-heron

docs.title: Hotspot Selection
docs.text:
• Say Next - Switches to next nearby hotspot in list
  • Say Insert checklist - Creates new checklist header at current position

docs.title: Reviewing Counts
docs.text:
• Say How many species - BirdTalk says back total species count for checklist
  • Say How many robins - BirdTalk says back total count for that species
  • Say How many species today - BirdTalk says back species count across all today's checklists
  • Say Choose [species] - Select most recent entry of specified species

docs.title: Adjusting Counts
docs.text:
• Say No, three - Changes count of last entry (e.g., from 2 to 3)
  • Say One more - Adds one to current count
  • Say One fewer - Subtracts one from current count
  • Say No, towhee - Changes species of last entry
  • Say Make that five total - Adjusts to reach specific total

docs.title: Corrections
docs.text:
• Say Scratch that - Removes last entry or memo
  • Say Restore - Restores last removed entry
  • Say Mark that - Marks entry for review (turns red)
  • Say Unmark that - Removes review mark
  • Say Unmark entire checklist - Removes all review marks

docs.title: Adding Comments
docs.text:
• Say Memo singing from oak tree - Adds comment to selected entry
  • Say Memo from scratch carrying nesting material - Replaces existing memo
  • Say Memo nest 10 meters north of coordinates - Includes coordinates from when bird was first entered
  • Say Memo nest at current coordinates - Includes coordinates of your current position

docs.title: Reading Comments
docs.text:
• Say Read back - BirdTalk says back current entry's memo
  • Say Read entire - BirdTalk says back all memos for current species

docs.title: Editing Comments
docs.text:
• Say Edit memo - Opens memo editor
  • Say Scratch that - Removes last added memo text

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
• Say Choose newest - Selects most recent entry
  • Say Sort by family - Groups entries by species
  • Say Sort by time - Shows entries chronologically
  • Say Show coordinates - Displays GPS coordinates

docs.title: Upload Management
docs.text:
• Say Upload later - Marks current checklist for later upload
  • Say Unfreeze - Marks an uploaded checklist as not uploaded (allows re-uploading if needed)

docs.title: Information
docs.text:
• Say How far - BirdTalk says back distance traveled
  • Say How long - BirdTalk says back elapsed time
  • Say Time - BirdTalk says back current time

docs.title: Device Management
docs.text:
• Say Mute or Ignore - Stops listening for commands
  • Say Resume or Listen or Unmute - Resumes listening

docs.title: System Commands
docs.text:
• Say Help - Shows command list
  • Say Back - Returns to main screen
  • Say Time - BirdTalk speaks current time (also confirms it's listening)
  • Say Feedback [text] - Stores feedback for later transmission (note: feedback is saved but not sent immediately)
  • Say Send feedback - Submits all stored feedback to developer

docs.title: Basic Codes
docs.text:
• Say robin singing
  • Say bluebird carrying food
  • Say chickadee feeding
  • Say wren nest with young
  • Say dove nest with eggs
  • Say towhee carrying nesting material

docs.title: Advanced Codes
docs.text:
• Say warbler physiological
  • Say flicker territorial
  • Say junco courtship
  • Say nuthatch visiting probable nest
  • Say jay agitated behavior
  • Say grosbeak pair in suitable habitat

docs.title: Santa Barbara Study Codes
docs.text:
• Say woodpecker nestling
  • Say chickadee feeding fledgling
  • Say quail family group
  • Say sparrow independent juvenile
  • Say swallow cavity nester attending cavity
  • Say towhee male singing on territory

docs.title: In noisy environments:
docs.text:
• Speak more clearly and slightly louder
  • Repeat exact phrase if not recognized
  • Wait for quiet moments
  • Try cupping your hand around the microphone

docs.title: For better accuracy:
docs.text:
• Use complete phrases
  • Maintain consistent volume
  • Speak at normal pace

docs.title: When using shorthand:
docs.text:
• Ensure phrase is unique in your region
  • Use distinctive parts of names
  • Check recognition with "Choose" command

For more detailed advice on voice recognition, shorthand names, and troubleshooting, see the Tips and Tricks guide.

docs.title: Essential Requirements
docs.text:
• iPhone 11 or newer
  • iOS 18.0 or later
  • At least 250MB of free storage space
  • Apple ID for TestFlight access
  • eBird account (create one at ebird.org if needed)

docs.title: Recommended Hardware
docs.text:
While BirdTalk works with your iPhone's built-in microphone, we strongly recommend using a Bluetooth headset for the best experience:

Recommended Model: OpenComm2 Bone Conduction Stereo Bluetooth Headset by Shokz

Key features:

  • Boom microphone for better voice recognition
  • Bone conduction keeps ears unobstructed for birding
  • Good noise isolation for the microphone

Optional Accessory: For improved voice recognition in windy conditions, some users report a good experience with using wind muffs (small foam covers) for the microphone:

Lavalier Wind Muff 2 Pack - These small foam covers significantly improve recognition accuracy in windy environments.

docs.title: Getting Beta Access
docs.text:
1. Email your request to stevebt@membot.com. Your email address will only be used for communications with you about setting up and operating BirdTalk.

  2. Include:

    • Your Apple ID email address
    • Your phone number (required for configuration)
    • Confirmation that you're willing to provide regular feedback to help improve the product

  3. Wait for email confirmation that you've been added as a beta tester

docs.title: Installing TestFlight
docs.text:
1. Open the App Store on your iPhone
  2. Search for "TestFlight"
  3. Download and install the TestFlight app
  4. Sign in with your Apple ID

docs.title: Installing BirdTalk
docs.text:
1. Open TestFlight
  2. Look for BirdTalk in available beta apps
  3. Tap "Install" next to BirdTalk
  4. Wait for installation to complete

docs.title: Internet Connectivity
docs.text:
• Required for initial setup and installation
  • Works offline in the field after initial setup
  • Need cellular connectivity to upload checklists to eBird

docs.title: Audio Setup
docs.text:
1. If using a Bluetooth headset:

    • Turn on your headset before starting BirdTalk
    • BirdTalk will automatically use the headset for audio

  2. Test voice recognition in both quiet and noisy environments

  3. For detailed audio troubleshooting, see Tips and Tricks

docs.title: Location Services
docs.text:
If the phone asks, enable GPS for use by BirdTalk.

  • Used for location recording with observations
  • Helps with checklist organization

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
1. Basic Tests:

    • Say Time to verify voice recognition
    • Tap the ? button at upper left of screen for available commands.

  2. First Checklist Test:

    • Go outdoors with GPS visibility
    • Say Start checklist
    • Say sparrow to add a bird to the checklist.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After successful installation:

  • Go to the Getting Started Guide for a quick run through the basic commands.

For installation support, contact us at stevebt@membot.com
